title: 110_hr6038
content: The Act may be cited as the "Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2008". The Federal Government aims to enhance its public alert and warning system by utilizing various technologies to provide timely and effective warnings of disasters. This modernization effort includes improving security, redundancy, remote notification capabilities, geographically targeted alerts, and the ability for individuals to request specific warnings. The goal is to alert residents of the United States of all potential hazards under any conditions. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System is being modernized to provide timely and effective disaster warnings using various technologies. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System is being modernized to ensure timely disaster warnings by the President through the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The system will alert governmental authorities and the civilian population in disaster-affected areas. The Director shall assign responsibility for advising on the modernization and implementation of the public alert and warning system, establish common protocols and standards, include capabilities for geographic adaptation and alerting individuals with disabilities or limited English proficiency. The public alert and warning system must incorporate multiple communication technologies, adapt to future technologies, provide alerts to a large portion of the population, promote partnerships for community preparedness, and have redundant alert mechanisms. The Director will conduct pilot programs to demonstrate the feasibility of various methods for meeting system requirements. Reports will be submitted to relevant committees periodically. The Director will conduct pilot programs to assess effectiveness and submit reports to relevant committees for further recommendations and findings. The Director will submit a detailed plan for implementing the subsection, including a timeline, spending plan, and recommendations for additional authority. $37,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009, with additional funding as needed in subsequent years. No impact on the authority of the Department of Commerce or the Federal Communications Commission.
